anchor.surface_text: On the 30th April, 1934, he requested the Collector to assess non-agricultural assessment on these plots. This request was refused by the Collector on the 17th July, 1935, in these terms-- With reference to your letter dated 30-4-1934, I have the honour to state that I regret your request cannot be granted. It has to be observed that this refusal was in contra- vention of the provisions of rule 92 which imposes on the Collector a duty to make alteration in the assessment, unless he has been directed to the contrary by Government.

concepts.interpretation: Imposes duty on Collector to alter assessment; contravention if refused without Govt direction

holdings.text: The Collector's refusal to assess non-agricultural assessment contravened Rule 92 as it imposes a duty to alter assessment unless directed otherwise by Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 92 imposes duty on Collector; no contrary direction existed at time of refusal.

holdings.text: Rule 92 in imperative terms directs the Collector to alter the assessment when agricultural land is used for non-agricultural purposes; Collector has no option.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 92 cited in the earlier part of this judgment in imper- ative terms directs the Collector to alter the assessment in case agricultural lands are Converted to number-agricultural use. The Collector has numberoption in the matter

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of Rule 92 is imperative; directs alteration unless otherwise directed.

holdings.text: The Commissioner contravened Rule 92 in dismissing the plaintiff's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner, in dismissing the plaintiffs appeal, also companytravened the provisions of rule

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal violated imperative duty under Rule 92.

holdings.text: Government's confirmation of Collector's action does not amount to a 'direction otherwise' under Rule 92.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court assumed that the companyfirmation of the action of the Collector by the Government amounted to a direction by the Government to the companytrary in respect of the lands in question. We are unable to agree with this companyclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere affirmation of erroneous order not equivalent to direction under the rule.

holdings.text: Any direction under Rule 92 by Government must be exercised in clear and unambiguous terms and notified, as it affects civil rights.

anchor.surface_text: When Gov- ernment has been given the power to give directions to the Collector number to act in accordance with the imperative provisions of a rule which enjoin upon him to make the altered assessment, that power has to be exercised in clear and unambiguous terms as it affects civil rights of the persons companycerned and the decision that the power has been exercised should be numberified in the usual manner in which such decisions are made known to the public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power affects civil rights; requires clarity and notification like other government decisions.

holdings.text: No resolution or notification under Rule 92 directing Collector not to alter assessment existed.

anchor.surface_text: It was companyceded by Mr. Joshi that numbersuch decision was taken by Government and numberdirection was issued by Government under rule 92

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded by counsel; no evidence of formal direction.

holdings.text: Plaintiff entitled to direction for levy of non-agricultural assessment on Schedule II lands and payment to him.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the plaintiff was clearly entitled to further relief in respect to lands mentioned in schedule II and a direction should have been issued to the State Government for making altered assessment on number-agricultural lands and levy it on them and pay it to the plaintiff.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Due to contravention of Rule 92 at all levels; no valid contrary direction.

holdings.text: High Court's relief for Schedule I lands (survey officer's refusal ultra vires) not in controversy; upheld.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy in this appeal as regards the reliefs that have been given to the plaintiff by the High Court. The appeal companycerns the fur- ther relief refused to the plaintiff in respect to the lands mentioned in schedule II.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No challenge to High Court's decision on Schedule I.

holdings.text: When a liability is imposed by statute, it cannot be defeated by exercise of discretion by Government.

anchor.surface_text: We think that when a liability is imposed by a statute, that liability cannot be defeated by the exercise of any discretion by Government or by making rules which may negative that liability, but it is number necessary in this case to finally decide the point as the appeal stands decided otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle on statutory liability vs discretion; not decided as unnecessary.
